parth.brahmbhatt:

Users should be able to do this even right now. Instead of using the default Schemes(StringScheme, RawScheme, StringKeyValueScheme etc.), users can specify their own scheme implementation which can output both the message and the topic.

Example:

Create your own implementation of Scheme

public class StringWithTopicScheme implements Scheme {

public static final String MESSAGE_KEY = "message";
public static final String TOPIC_KEY = "topic";

private String topicName;

public StringWithTopicScheme(String topicName)

{ this.topicName = topicName; }

public List
Actually your issue is fixed by #174, but PR may help for other modification.

kabhwan:

I've tried to reproduce your situation with storm-starter, and it doesn't reproduced.

I've modified your situation to use 3 machines(A, B, C - A has nimbus, too.), which has 4 ports. (total 12 ports) And I've modified storm-starter to use 6 workers.
After submitting jar, 2 workers are created for each machine. 6 ports are remained.

I had shutdown B's supervisor to restrict resurrection and kill all workers belong to B.
Then all remaining workers was trying to reconnect killed workers. (as we expected)

But Nimbus recognized failed workers and reallocate workers to other ports.
Alive workers recognized new workers (with clean up connection with killed workers) and continue their tasks.

kabhwan:

So you can review some checkpoints.

1. Did Nimbus recognized failure of first worker? If then, did Nimbus try to reassign new worker?
2. Was there free slots to reassign?
3. Can you check these options?
(Please try to see your version of defaults.yml or your custom setting, since it's current master's value.)

nimbus.task.timeout.secs: 30
nimbus.supervisor.timeout.secs: 60
nimbus.task.launch.secs: 120
nimbus.reassign: true
#how long supervisor will wait to ensure that a worker process is started
supervisor.worker.start.timeout.secs: 120
#how long between heartbeats until supervisor considers that worker dead and tries to restart it
supervisor.worker.timeout.secs: 30
#how frequently the supervisor checks on the status of the processes it's monitoring and restarts if necessary
supervisor.monitor.frequency.secs: 3
#how frequently the supervisor heartbeats to the cluster state (for nimbus)
supervisor.heartbeat.frequency.secs: 5
supervisor.enable: true
worker.heartbeat.frequency.secs: 1
task.heartbeat.frequency.secs: 3
# Since nimbus.task.launch.secs and supervisor.worker.start.timeout.secs are 120, other workers should also wait at least that long before giving up on connecting to the other worker.
storm.messaging.netty.max_retries: 300
storm.messaging.netty.max_wait_ms: 1000
storm.messaging.netty.min_wait_ms: 100

Btw, if first machine cannot find nimbus host, did first machine's supervisor work properly?
Did supervisor send heartbeat to Nimbus?

kabhwan:

Btw, we can fix it to not crash while accessing closed netty client.
If Nimbus or supervisor eventually assigned new worker, closed client may be cleaned up (as I think).

If it makes sense, I'll try to make a PR.

akrishnan4doittnyc:

We are seeing the problem exists in the Firefox browser, but appears to be suppressed in the Chrome browser.

Additionally, we are currently using Storm version 0.9.0.1 which does not use the mustache.js templates. We will explore upgrading to solve this problem. Thanks.

Github user xiaokang commented on a diff in the pull request:

https://github.com/apache/incubator-storm/pull/36#discussion_r16298432

— Diff: storm-core/test/clj/backtype/storm/scheduler_test.clj —
@@ -259,3 +260,27 @@
(is (= false (.isSlotOccupied cluster (WorkerSlot. "supervisor1" (int 3)))))
(is (= false (.isSlotOccupied cluster (WorkerSlot. "supervisor1" (int 5)))))
))
+
+(deftest test-sort-slots
+ ;; test supervisor1 and supervisor2 has the same free slot
+ (is (= '(["supervisor1" 6700] ["supervisor2" 6700]
+ ["supervisor1" 6701] ["supervisor2" 6701])
+ (sort-slots [["supervisor1" 6700] ["supervisor1" 6701] ["supervisor2" 6700] ["supervisor2" 6701]])))
— End diff –

Yes, the order is not defined for supervisors with the same free slots.

— Diff: storm-core/test/clj/backtype/storm/scheduler_test.clj —
@@ -259,3 +260,27 @@
(is (= false (.isSlotOccupied cluster (WorkerSlot. "supervisor1" (int 3)))))
(is (= false (.isSlotOccupied cluster (WorkerSlot. "supervisor1" (int 5)))))
))
+
+(deftest test-sort-slots
+ ;; test supervisor1 and supervisor2 has the same free slot
+ (is (= '(["supervisor1" 6700] ["supervisor2" 6700]
+ ["supervisor1" 6701] ["supervisor2" 6701])
+ (sort-slots [["supervisor1" 6700] ["supervisor1" 6701] ["supervisor2" 6700] ["supervisor2" 6701]])))
+ ;; test supervisor2 has more free slots
+ (is (= '(["supervisor2" 6700] ["supervisor1" 6700]
+ ["supervisor2" 6701] ["supervisor1" 6701]
+ ["supervisor2" 6702])
+ (sort-slots [["supervisor1" 6700] ["supervisor1" 6701]
+ ["supervisor2" 6700] ["supervisor2" 6701] ["supervisor2" 6702]
+ ])))
+ ;; test supervisor3 has more free slots
+ (is (= '(["supervisor3" 6700] ["supervisor2" 6700] ["supervisor1" 6700]
+ ["supervisor3" 6701] ["supervisor2" 6701] ["supervisor1" 6701]
+ ["supervisor3" 6702] ["supervisor2" 6702]
+ ["supervisor3" 6703])
+ (sort-slots [["supervisor1" 6700] ["supervisor1" 6701]
+ ["supervisor2" 6700] ["supervisor2" 6701] ["supervisor2" 6702]
+ ["supervisor3" 6700] ["supervisor3" 6701] ["supervisor3" 6702] ["supervisor3" 6703]
+ ])))
+ )
— End diff –

The port numbers will be in the same order as they are given in the arguments, since 'group-by' and 'vals' function both keep order of input collection or sequence. I also changed the port numbers order in the tests to make sure about this.
Thanks for @d2r 's comments and the test code is updated.

dagit:

Thanks, Naresh. I merged this to master.

- build and ran all tests with this change merged to master, passed
- set up a cluster with two supervisors with 6 slots each, and launched word_count twice.  Each word_count topology uses 3 workers, so I verified that after the second one is launched, the number of slots used for both of the supervisors is 3.  Without this change, the same test results in 4 slots used by one supervisor, and 2 by the other.

+1, and thanks for your patience, @xiaokang

revans2:

Not totally sure what is happening here. If your PHP is stuck writing to stdout then like you said the spout is probably not reading that in.

https://github.com/apache/incubator-storm/blob/master/storm-core/src/jvm/backtype/storm/spout/ShellSpout.java?source=c

has the shell spout code. It will read from the stdout of the php process when nextTuple, ack, or fail is called, and then it will drain the queue until a sync command is returned. Do you have a stack trace of the java process when this happens so you know what it is doing at this time?

@SeanTAllen

I am happy to merge this in as is, but a lot of our tracking of changes goes through JIRA so if you want fully credit with your name in bright lights for your contribution please file a JIRA for this change and add the JIRA number to the title of this pull request.  If you don't care that is fine too.
don't care anywhere near enough to open a jira.

revans2:

Thanks Gabriel and Viktor Taranenko for your help on this. I merged it into master.

revans2:

I just duped STORM-450 to this one, because this was filed first. The exception is thrown when the client is shutting down. The client is shutting down in one of two cases. Either the client is shutting down, or it gets a message with a task id of -1. If it were shut down because it got the -1 message then it would log "Receiving-thread:[" storm-id ", " port "] received shutdown notice". I didn't see that in your logs, so I have to assume that the process itself was already going to shut down. But I don't know for sure.

Is this a reproducible use case for you? It only showed up once for me. If it is then I would be happy to help debug this.

revans2:

If you just don't want to throw I think that is OK, but I am a bit nervous that we might end up eating a lot of messages waiting for another client to come up.
+1 too, @d2r if you want to you can file a JIRA for this issue, and check it in without fully linking the two.

Github user d2r commented on a diff in the pull request:

https://github.com/apache/incubator-storm/pull/223#discussion_r16433290

— Diff: storm-core/src/jvm/backtype/storm/task/ShellBolt.java —
@@ -293,11 +295,13 @@ private void handleMetrics(ShellMsg shellMsg) {

private void die(Throwable exception) {

  • String processInfo = _process.getProcessInfoString() + _process.getProcessTerminationInfoString();
  • _exception = new RuntimeException(processInfo, exception);
  • LOG.error("Halting process: ShellBolt died.", exception);
  • _collector.reportError(exception);
  • System.exit(11);
    +if (_running) { //Don't exit if running tests
      • End diff –

Let's change the comment to me non-specific to tests. If we aren't running, don't bother.

}

— End diff –

If this `Throwable` is an error, we would still want to log it somewhere as well as shut down.
